paragraph.paragraph: EiffelEnvision projects cannot reference other EiffelEnvision projects using the urfAddReferenceDialogBox 0 Project tab of the vxurfComponentSelectorDialogBoxS 0 Component Selector Dialog Box , as you would be able to do when referencing, say EiffelEnvision projects from Visual C# or vice-versa.

The mode of reuse is through Precompiled Libraries. This mode of binary reuses, as apposed to referencing assemblies directly, overcomes some of the limitations imposed by the .NET Framework and the Common Language Runtime (CLR). Precompiled libraries permit ongoing support for many of the features elided from other languages, some of which are mention later in this document.

heading.content: Overcoming the Limitations of the CLR

paragraph.paragraph: The url*Eiffel for .NET language compiler is complex compared to that of the Visual C#, Visual Basic .NET and many other compilers. Both the Eiffel Language and the url*Eiffel for .NET compiler support many concepts and language attributes that are not natively supported by the .NET framework; features such as url*Multiple Inheritance and url*Generics. To adapt to the underlying CLR, the url*Eiffel for .NET compiler generates code which will not directly reflect the code class for class, often generating additional classes or varying the class name to appease the CLR. As a consequence the assemblies generated by the url*Eiffel for .NET compiler in EiffelEnvision cannot be referenced directly from other EiffelEnvision projects.
As a mean of demonstration of one of the more basic issues concerning Generics regarding this adaptation, imagine the following Eiffel class declaration in an EiffelEnvision project.
paragraph.code_block:
class GENERIC_CLASS [G -> ANY]
inherit ARRAY [G] redefine make end
create make
feature {NONE} -- Initialization
make (n: INTEGER) is -- Initialize instance. do Precursor {ARRAY} (n)
-- Other initialization logic end
end -- GENERIC_CLASS
paragraph.paragraph: The .NET Framework and the CLR do not currently support url*Generics, but in the example two generic classes are specified; the GENERIC_CLASS is declared as with formal generic parameter, making it a Generic class, and ARRAY, a generic class from EiffelBase is being inherited.

To resolve this non-supportive issue, the url*Eiffel for .NET compiler will subsequently generate a GENERIC_CLASS_X where the _X suffix is the name of the actual generic parameter specified when making use of the GENERIC_CLASS class. This means GENERIC_CLASS [INTEGER] would yield GENERIC_CLASS_INTEGER.

The problem with referencing the assembly with the type GENERIC_CLASS_X is that GENERIC_CLASS_X is no longer a generic class stunting GENERIC_CLASS's orginal usage intention. This will become an issue when facets of future projects require the original genericity of GENERIC_CLASS.
Dealing with the issue of url*Multiple Inheritance in a single implementation inheritance framework is far more complex than the issue with generics. This will not be discussed in this documentation.

The answer to the problem of assembly reuse when you want to use an EiffelEnvision project from another EiffelEnvision project is to use precompiled libraries. Precompiled libraries are similar to class library projects, but the url*Eiffel for .NET compiler generates extra compilation information so two projects can be "merged." At first it may seem like the contents of a precompiled library will end up in a referencing project's, but this is not the case. The url*Eiffel for .NET compiler will only put the contents of the project in a generated assembly, and that assembly in turn will reference the precompiled library's assembly, just in the way System.dll references mscorlib.dll, in System.dll's assembly manifest.

Only one precompiled library can be referenced per project. This does mean that if you want to reference multiple precompiled libraries, it is required that you build each in an incremental fashion and then reference the top most precompiled library in your project.

Precompiled libraries can be specified by selecting the folder containing the precompiled library compiler information. This folder will always contain a precomp.epr (Eiffel Project file). In EiffelEnvision, the location of the precomp.epr will always be in a precompiled library's ProjectName\obj\ConfigurationName folder. To specify a precompiled library, use the url*Precompiled Library Properties.

Using precompiled libraries is not essential by any means. Eiffel's principle reuse has always been on source code reuse, hence the notion of url*clusters, which reference other "libraries" of code. The use of precompiled libraries, however, will make initial code compilations faster, reduce debug startup times and create much smaller assemblies for the projects that use them.

Precompiled libraries can be optimized. When choosing to url*Optimize Code for the precompiled library, a debug version and an optimized version of the precompiled library assembly will be generated. Projects using the precompiled library can specify to Use Optimized Precompile in the Precompiled Library Properties. When set to Yes the debug version will be used in referencing project configurations with url*Optimize Code se to No and the optimized version will be used when Yes is selected.
Recommended: It recommended that you always create precompiled libraries with the url*Optimize Code set to Yes in all vxconBuildConfigurations 0 Build Configurations .

EiffelEnvision has a new project template for precompiled libraries. The new project is called Eiffel Class Library Project.
Recommended: Due to the nature of precompiled libraries, when modified, projects will be cause a Rebuild to be performed instead of a standard Build, regardless of selecting Build. EiffelEnvision projects are compiled on an as-needed basis, so it is recommended that you only use Eiffel Class Library Projects for projects that do not change often.
